hints_html: Simplifying first will make your life easier.
hints_latex: Simplifying first will make your life easier.
hints_raw: Simplifying first will make your life easier.
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
If we start by simplifying the expression of the function \(f\) we have:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x^2x^3x^4x^5x^6}{x} = \frac{x^{20}}{x}\end{aligned}\]

This function is not defined at 0 and for all the other value, we can divide and obtain that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x^{20}}{x} = x^{19} \quad \text{if }x \neq 0\end{aligned}\]

and so its derivative is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = 19 x^{18} \quad \text{if }x \neq 0\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
If we start by simplifying the expression of the function &fnof; we have:
:<math>\displaystyle
f(x) = \frac{x^2x^3x^4x^5x^6}{x} = \frac{x^{20}}{x}
</math>
This function is not defined at 0 and for all the other value, we can divide and obtain that
:<math>\displaystyle
f(x) = \frac{x^{20}}{x} = x^{19} \quad \text{if }x \neq 0
</math>
and so its derivative is
:<math>\displaystyle
f'(x) = 19 x^{18} \quad \text{if }x \neq 0
</math>
statement_html:
Find the derivative of the following function.

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x^2x^3x^4x^5x^6}{x}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
''Find the derivative of the following function.''

:<math>\displaystyle
f(x) = \frac{x^2x^3x^4x^5x^6}{x}
</math>
